text: Introduction: Indeed, all praise is due to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our own selves and from our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is none to mislead him, and whomever He misleads, there is none to guide him. I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah alone, who has no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, may Allah’s peace and blessings be upon him, his family, his companions, and those who follow them in righteousness until the Day of Judgment. As for what follows. The occurrence of an epidemic is a divine way decreed by the wisdom of the Almighty, and He willed it by His decree and destiny. Nothing happens in this universe except what Allah wills and desires, and He, Glory be to Him, does not lift harm and affliction from the servants and lands unless He wills, when He wills, and how He wills. The epidemic is among the trials with which Allah tests His servants; whoever is patient will have a good reward in this world and a great reward in the Hereafter, and whoever panics has failed in his work in this world and lost his reward in the Hereafter. When an epidemic strikes, servants must turn to Allah alone, seek help and hope from Him alone, and pray to Him alone to lift the affliction; for no one is capable of this affliction nor can anyone repel this epidemic except Allah, and anything else is merely a cause that He, Glory be to Him, approved of occurring and permitted its benefit. It is also incumbent upon them, when an epidemic strikes, to have knowledge and insight into Islamic law regarding the acts of worship or beliefs they perform, and they must beware of innovation or doing what contradicts the fundamentals of religion when performing these acts of worship or beliefs; for through knowledge, doubts that veil the truth are removed, and violations that cause deviation from the religion and distance from the Sunnah are recognized. Epidemics have occurred in Muslim lands in many times and various places, and the first epidemic that occurred in the history of Muslims was the Plague of Amwas (1), which happened during the reign of Caliph Umar, may Allah be pleased with him.

A town in Palestine near Jerusalem, from which the plague began in the days of Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, then it spread in the land of Sham, and a countless number of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and others died in it, in the year (18 AH). See: Mu'jam al-Buldan, al-Hamawi, (4/ 157 - 158).

text: The Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, dealt with this plague in the most ideal and best way; it was the custom of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, that if a calamity befell them, they would gather with their leader and consult about it, research and discuss it, then come out with an opinion in which they agreed with their leader and did not object to him. When Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, went out to Sham, the commanders of the armies, Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah and his companions, met him and informed him that the epidemic had broken out in the land of Sham. Umar said: Call the early Muhajireen (Emigrants) for me. So he called them and consulted them, informing them that the epidemic had broken out in Sham. They differed; some said: You have come out for a matter, and we do not think you should turn back from it. Others said: You have the rest of the people and the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and we do not think you should expose them to this epidemic. He said: Leave me. Then he said: Call the Ansar (Helpers) for me. So I called them and he consulted them, and they followed the way of the Muhajireen and differed just as they differed. He said: Leave me. Then he said: Call for me whoever is here of the elders of Quraysh from the Emigrants of the Conquest. So I called them, and not two of them differed on him. They said: We think you should return with the people and not expose them to this epidemic. So Umar announced among the people: I am setting out in the morning on a mount, so set out in the morning. Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah said: Is it fleeing from the decree of Allah? Umar said: If only someone other than you had said it, O Abu Ubaidah? Yes, we flee from the decree of Allah to the decree of Allah. Do you not see that if you had camels that descended into a valley with two sides, one fertile and the other barren, is it not that if you grazed them on the fertile side, you grazed them by the decree of Allah, and if you grazed them on the barren side, you grazed them by the decree of Allah? He said: Then Abdurrahman bin Awf came - and he had been absent for some need - and said: I have knowledge regarding this. I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "If you hear about it in a land, do not enter it; and if it breaks out in a land while you are there, do not leave it fleeing from it." He said: So Umar praised Allah and then departed (1). Many Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, died in this plague, including: Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah, Mu'adh bin Jabal, Yazid bin Abi Sufyan, Al-Harith bin Hisham, Suhail bin Amr, and Utbah bin Suhail, may Allah be pleased with him (2). Some historians estimated that about twenty-five thousand Muslims died in this epidemic (3).

text: This plague is considered the first doctrinal new occurrence (Nawazil) related to epidemics in the lives of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, after the death of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Their dealing with this epidemic, may Allah be pleased with them, was the ideal dealing based on consultation and unity, and on following (Sunnah) and not innovating. No doctrinal violation or invented innovation occurred from them that contradicted the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. This dealing should be a role model for the Ummah when epidemics strike, and an example to be followed when cosmic events occur and times change. By seeking help from Allah and then reading what was possible to read of the Nawazil, the most important of these occurrences that took place have been identified and limited, and the most important of these incidents that happened with the onset of the Coronavirus epidemic have been tracked. Doctrinal issues related to the Coronavirus epidemic require precision in knowing whether they are a Nazilah (new occurrence) or not, and correct determination of whether they are new in their occurrence or renewed in their content. Definitions of terms, the difference between an epidemic and a plague, an explanation of these Nawazil, a discussion of the deviations that occurred in these Nawazil, and the correct doctrinal direction and the rooted scientific response to these Nawazil will be presented, God willing. This is a statement of the most important doctrinal Nawazil related to the Coronavirus epidemic, which are as follows: * The First Nazilah: Doctrinal violations in graves and places; for treatment from the Coronavirus epidemic. * The Second Nazilah: Uttering violative supplications and remembrances; for treatment from the Coronavirus epidemic. * The Third Nazilah: Tawassul (seeking intercession) through other than Allah; to lift the affliction of the Coronavirus epidemic. * The Fourth Nazilah: Wrong application of legal evidences when the Coronavirus epidemic strikes. * The Fifth Nazilah: Abandoning legal evidences and relying on rational evidences. * The Sixth Nazilah: Calling for reliance on medical treatments only, and abandoning everything related to religion. * The Seventh Nazilah: The belief that the Coronavirus epidemic is mentioned in the Quran. * The Eighth Nazilah: Alleging that the Coronavirus epidemic is man-made. * The Ninth Nazilah: Astrology and claiming knowledge of the unseen regarding the Coronavirus epidemic. * The Tenth Nazilah: Issues related to hearing and obeying the ruler.

text: First: Definition of doctrinal Nawazil related to the Coronavirus epidemic. Definition of Nawazil: Linguistically: The Nun, Zaa, and Lam form a valid word indicating the descent of something and its falling (1), and 'Nazala bihi al-amr' means: the matter befell him (2). A Nazilah is a severe hardship that descends upon them with a great matter (3), and it is said to be: Calamity and distress from the hardships of time that befall people (4), as the poet said: And many a calamity narrows the youth's ... capability, while with Allah is the way out from it (5). Terminologically: Some scholars used the term Nazilah in its linguistic meaning mentioned above, so it was said to be: The incident that requires a legal ruling (6), or new occurrences for which there is no previous text or ijtihad (7). And it was said to be: The event and incident that befalls a person, whether in the field of acts of worship, transactions, or behavior and morals; where this person resorts to someone to give him a fatwa on the legal ruling for his calamity (8). And it was said: They are the new matters and issues that arise with the development of times and the difference of eras and places (9). For a Nazilah, three things are required: its occurrence and not being hypothetical, its novelty and non-repetition, and the intensity of its urgency in seeking a legal ruling for it; and based on that, its definition is: It is what called for a legal ruling from new occurrences (10).

text: However, the concept of Nawazil in contemporary issues and questions rarely applies completely to the description of a Nazilah as purely novel, meaning something that has not happened before; mostly what scholars mention in contemporary issues as Nawazil may be described as relative novelty, meaning they are things that have happened before but are renewed. Some of them happened before but have evolved, or the reality surrounding them has changed, or their causes have changed, or people needed them due to necessity or interest; so they became in dire need of being researched again. Accordingly, any doctrinal issue can be termed a Nazilah if one of the following reasons is realized in it: First: Variance in the origin of the doctrinal issue in some aspects; such as a change in its causes, its development, and a change in the reality surrounding it. Second: The occurrence of renewal in the conditions of some doctrinal issues, so that they became like a new Nazilah. Third: Some new doctrinal issues may be Nawazil in the convention of some scholars; according to their own view of the issue. Fourth: When there is an urgent need to seek a sufficient solution for the subject or content of the doctrinal issue. Definition of Doctrine (Aqidah): Linguistically: Derived from 'Al-Aqd': which is tying and tightening strongly, or covenant, or adhering, or confirmation (1), and 'Aqada qalbah' upon something: he did not withdraw from it (2), and 'I'taqadtu kadha': meaning I tied my heart and conscience upon it, until it was said: Doctrine is what a person professes religiously (3). Terminologically: It is the firm belief in Allah, and what is due to Him in His divinity, lordship, names and attributes, and belief in His angels, books, messengers, the Last Day, and destiny, its good and its evil, and in everything brought by the authentic texts from the fundamentals of religion and matters of the unseen and its news, and what the righteous predecessors agreed upon, and submission to Allah Almighty in judgment, command, decree, and legislation, and to His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, in obedience and following (4).

text: Second: The difference between the Coronavirus epidemic and the plague: Scholars differed in the past on the issue of differentiating between an epidemic and a plague on two opinions, and this differentiation includes epidemics in general and applies to the Coronavirus epidemic; because it is classified among epidemics. The scholars' opinions regarding the difference between plague and epidemic are as follows: The First Opinion: That plague is the epidemic: This opinion is held by some scholars of language and early Arab physicians. Al-Khalil, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The epidemic: The plague, and it was said: It is every general disease (1). Ibn Sidah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The epidemic is the plague, and it was said: It is every general disease (2). Ibn Al-Athir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The general disease and the epidemic for which the air corrupts, so humors and bodies corrupt due to it (3). Ibn Manzur, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The Waba': The plague with short, long, and hamza endings. And it was said it is every general disease (4). Al-Fayumi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: And the plague is death from the epidemic, and the plural is Tawa'in, and 'Tu'ina al-insan' in passive form means he was struck by the plague, so he is 'Mat'un' (plagued) (5). Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said: A group of physicians said, among them Abu Ali bin Sina: Plague is a toxic substance that causes a deadly swelling occurring in the soft places and armpits of the body, and mostly it is under the armpit or behind the ear or at the nose tip. He said: And its cause is bad blood leaning towards putrefaction and corruption turning into a toxic essence that corrupts the organ and changes what is next to it, and leads to the heart a bad quality causing vomiting, nausea, fainting, and palpitations, and due to its badness it does not accept from the organs except what was weakest by nature, and the worst of it is what falls in the main organs. The black one, few survive from it, and the safest is the red then the yellow. Plagues abound during an epidemic in epidemic-stricken lands, and hence plague was called epidemic and vice versa (6).

text: Also, some Maliki and Hanafi scholars held this opinion. Al-Qadi Al-Baji, may Allah have mercy on him, says: The epidemic is the plague, it is a disease that pervades many people in one direction of directions without others, contrary to the usual condition of people and their diseases, and their illness is mostly one illness, unlike other times for people's illnesses are different (1). Ibn Juzayy, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The plague is the epidemic, and if it breaks out in a land, whoever is in it should not leave it fleeing from it, nor should anyone come to it (2). Ibn Abidin, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Epidemic is a name for every general disease, so every plague in that sense is an epidemic (3). The Second Opinion: That the plague is other than the epidemic: This is the opinion held by some verifying scholars of Sharia from the people of Hadith and Fiqh. Al-Qadi Iyad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The origin of the plague is the ulcers emerging on the body, and the epidemic: The generality of diseases, so they were called plague; due to their resemblance in destruction to that, otherwise every plague is an epidemic, and not every epidemic is a plague (4). An-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The correct view which the verifiers said is that it is an illness of many people in one direction of the earth without other directions, and it is contrary to the usual illnesses in abundance and other things, and their illness is of one type unlike other times for their illnesses in them are different. They said: And every plague is an epidemic and not every epidemic is a plague (5). Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The investigation is that between the epidemic and the plague is generality and specificity, so every plague is an epidemic, and not every epidemic is a plague. Likewise, general diseases are more general than the plague, for it is one of them. Plagues are abscesses, ulcers, and bad tumors occurring in places (6).

text: Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said: As for the epidemic, it is the corruption of the essence of the air which is the material of the spirit and its support. I say: This is what has reached us from the words of linguists, jurists, and physicians regarding its definition. The conclusion is that its reality is a tumor arising from the agitation of blood, or the pouring of blood to an organ causing it to corrupt. Other than that of general diseases arising from air corruption are called plague by way of metaphor; due to their sharing in the generality of the disease, or the abundance of death (1). Al-Suyuti, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The epidemic is other than the plague..., and the plague is distinguished by being martyrdom, mercy, and the supplication of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, unlike the epidemic (2). Al-Haytami, may Allah have mercy on him, said: By this, it is known that the plague is more specific than the epidemic absolutely, so every plague is an epidemic, and not the reverse, ... and some inferred that it is authentically reported that the plague does not enter Medina, and it is authentically reported from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that Medina is the most epidemic-prone land of Allah, and from Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him, that Medina is the land of the epidemic; so it implies that the plague is other than the epidemic (3). What is preferred in this issue, and Allah knows best, is the second opinion, i.e., the opinion of the Sharia scholars from the people of Hadith and Fiqh who argued for differentiating between the plague and the epidemic, and that every plague is an epidemic, and not every epidemic is a plague, and that the epidemic includes the plague and other diseases, and between them is generality and specificity. Among the evidences supporting this opinion are the following: First: Plague does not enter Medina: It is established in Hadiths that the plague does not enter Medina, while the epidemic enters Medina, and it was reported that it entered Medina during the era of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, as in the following Hadiths: On the authority of Abu 'Assib, may Allah be pleased with him, the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Gabriel came to me with the fever and the plague, so I kept the fever in Medina, and sent the plague to Sham. So the plague is a martyrdom for my nation, and a mercy, and a filth upon the disbeliever" (4).

text: And on the authority of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Neither the plague nor the Dajjal will enter Medina" (1). In another narration: "Medina and Mecca are surrounded by angels; on every gap of it is an angel, neither the Dajjal nor the plague enters it" (2). A Hadith was reported from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that the entry of the plague was not with certainty but suspended on will: "The Dajjal comes to Medina and finds the angels guarding it, so the Dajjal does not approach it," he said: "Nor the plague, if Allah wills" (3). There was disagreement regarding the exception "if Allah Almighty wills", it was said: It is for blessing so it includes both, and it was said: It is for suspension, and that it is specific to the plague, and that its implication is the permissibility of the plague entering Medina (4). And it was said: The non-entry of the Dajjal into Medina is certain, but the plague has not yet entered it, and that is what is hoped for in the future (5). A group of scholars mentioned that the general plague entered Mecca, but as for Medina, it was not mentioned that it entered it, and this is one of his miracles; because physicians were unable to repel the plague from a city, or even a village, and the plague has been prevented from Medina for long ages (6). Whichever [name] you call - to Him belong the best names."} [Al-Isra: 110], and the Almighty's saying: {And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them} [Al-A'raf: 180], meaning call upon Allah by His names which He named Himself with, or His Messenger named Him with. In it is evidence that the names of Allah Almighty are based on revelation (Tawqifiyyah) not convention. What indicates the correctness of this statement and confirms it: That it is permissible to say 'Ya Jawad' (O Generous), and it is not permissible to say 'Ya Sakhiy' (O Generous - synonym not used in text), and it is permissible to say 'Ya 'Alim' (O All-Knowing), and it is not permissible to say 'Ya 'Aqil' (O Rational) (2). Al-Qadi Iyad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Allah permitted supplicating to Him and taught supplication in His Book to His creation, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, taught supplication to his nation. Three things combined in it: Knowledge of Monotheism, knowledge of language, and advice to the nation. So no one should deviate from his supplication, peace and blessings be upon him. Satan has tricked people from this standpoint; so he assigned to them evil people who invent supplications for them that distract them from following the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him (3). Al-Qurtubi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: So a person must use what is in the Book of Allah and the authentic Sunnah of supplication and leave what is other than that, and not say I choose such and such, for Allah Almighty has chosen for His Prophet and His allies and taught them how to supplicate (4).

text: The doctrinal direction regarding this calamity is as follows: First: Allah guided His servants in their necessities and needs to sincerely supplicate to Him alone, Glory be to Him, excluding others, as He said: {And when My servants ask you concerning Me, indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me [by obedience] and believe in Me that they may be [rightly] guided (186)} [Al-Baqarah: 186]. And He said: {And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you." Indeed, those who disdain My worship will enter Hell [rendered] contemptible (60)} [Ghafir: 60]. And the Almighty said: {Is He [not best] who responds to the desperate one when he calls upon Him and removes evil and makes you inheritors of the earth? Is there a deity with Allah? Little do you remember (62)} [An-Naml: 62]. Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, says: The Lord, Glory be to Him, loves for His servant to ask Him and desire Him; because the arrival of His kindness and benevolence to him depends on his asking. Rather, He is the One who bestows it initially without a cause from the servant, nor the mediation of his asking and request. Rather, He decreed that favor for him without a cause from the servant, then He commanded him to ask Him and request from Him; to manifest the status of servitude, poverty, and need, and to acknowledge the might of Lordship and the perfection of the Lord's richness, and His uniqueness in favor and benevolence, and that the servant has no independence from His favor for the blink of an eye. So he comes with the request and asking in the manner of one who knows that he does not deserve anything by his request and asking; but his Lord, the Exalted, loves to be asked, desired, and requested from (1). Second: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not command the recitation of the Qur'an or reading any Hadith to repel harm, bring benefit, or resist an enemy. Rather, he commanded supplication, and he guided to supplication by his action and speech. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said when seeking victory: "O Allah, Revealer of the Book, Mover of the clouds, Defeater of the clans, defeat them and grant us victory over them (2)." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said in the prayer for rain: "O Allah, relieve us, O Allah, relieve us, O Allah, relieve us (3)." Third: That was not the guidance of the Companions, and they were the people who most honored the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; they did not worship by reciting Hadith except for memorization and transmission. Indeed, they did not command people to recite the Qur'an if a necessity befell them

Or that the servant seeks means to Allah Almighty by his acts of worship, whether of the heart, action, or speech, or others, as in the story of the three companions of the cave. text: As for the prohibited types of Tawassul, they are: Seeking means to Allah Almighty by the essence (Dhat) of a prophet or a righteous servant, or the Kaaba, or other virtuous things; or seeking means by the right (Haqq) of a prophet or a righteous servant or the Kaaba or others; or seeking means by the status (Jah) of a prophet or a righteous servant, or his blessing, or his sanctity, or by the right of his grave, and similar things. text: The correct doctrinal direction for this calamity is as follows: First: It is incorrect to describe the Corona epidemic as being a soldier from the soldiers of Allah; because the verse: {And none knows the soldiers of your Lord except Him} [Al-Muddathir: 31], came in the context of describing the angels with this description, and there is no evidence or legal justification indicating contrary to this description. This opinion is what scholars of interpretation and others mentioned, that the verse only comes in describing the angels and inferring by them. Among the evidences that clarify this matter is what was reported in the Hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, told them about the night he was taken on the Night Journey, he said: "I ascended, I and Gabriel, to the lowest heaven, and there was an angel called Ismail, who is the keeper of the lowest heaven, and before him were seventy thousand angels, with each angel his army of one hundred thousand," and he recited this verse: {And none knows the soldiers of your Lord except Him} [Al-Muddathir: 31] (1). text: The correct doctrinal direction for this calamity is as follows: First: Believing that these diseases and epidemics are effective without the decree and will of Allah Almighty is a belief that impugns Tawhid (Monotheism); because there is nothing that is independent in effect without the will of Allah Almighty, and causes, however great, have no effect except by the permission of Allah Almighty. Allah Almighty said regarding the sorcerers: {But they do not harm anyone through it except by permission of Allah} [Al-Baqarah: 102], meaning by the decree of Allah (1), for nothing happens except by His will and volition, Glory be to Him (2). Allah Almighty legislated for us to take means, and commanded us to do so in many places, and seeking treatment with cures and medicines is part of taking means. The believer realizes Tawhid, so he knows that the entire matter belongs to Allah, and he complies with the Sharia so he takes means and uses everything that has benefit for his body and health. Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, says: The Ahl al-Sunnah do not deny the existence of causes created by Allah nor do they make them independent in effects. Rather, they know that there is no created cause except that its ruling depends on another cause, and it has impediments that prevent its ruling. Just as the sun is a cause for rays, and that depends on the presence of a body capable of receiving it, and it has an impediment like clouds and a roof. And Allah is the Creator of all causes, and the Repeller of impediments (3). As for the servant relying on causes completely with the belief that they benefit independently of Allah, this is major Shirk. And if he relied on the cause while believing that Allah is the One who benefits and harms, then he has fallen into minor Shirk. So the believer is commanded to perform the cause while relying on the Causer of causes, Glorified and Exalted is He. And if he leaves the causes and believes that the Sharia commanded leaving them and that they have no benefit, then he falls into opposition to what Allah commanded. He [Ibn Taymiyyah] says, may Allah have mercy on him: Therefore, a group of scholars said: Turning to causes [excessively] is Shirk in Tawhid, and erasing causes from being causes is a deficiency in reason, and turning away from causes completely is a defamation of the Sharia. Reliance (Tawakkul) that is commanded is what combines the requirements of Tawhid, reason, and Sharia (4).

text: The Tenth Occurrence: Issues Related to Hearing and Obeying the Ruler. Among the doctrinal occurrences and issues that arose with the onset of the Corona epidemic are issues related to hearing and obeying instructions and adhering to procedures imposed by government agencies assigned by the ruler; so that the epidemic is contained and its non-spread is achieved, God willing. The Kingdom was among the first countries to adopt precautionary health measures and preventive actions in dealing with the Corona epidemic; it added innovative concepts in crisis management, and presented a model to the world in its dealing with the repercussions of the situation health-wise, socially, and economically, unique in its humanitarian values, differentiating not between citizen and expatriate on its soil. Crisis management in the Kingdom was characterized by an integrated approach of the governmental, civil, and voluntary work system, its primary goal being preserving public health according to approved standards. It was distinguished by investigation and scrutiny of health threats, assessing the degree of risks, and preparedness with firm preventive measures in their implementation. Therefore, the results of the Ministry of Health's Command and Control Center monitoring the infection level of the (covid-19) virus in Wuhan (WHAN), China, drove the Kingdom's early response to confront the virus's repercussions. The Royal Order was issued on: Jan 26, 2020 AD, to form a supreme committee concerned with taking all precautionary measures and necessary actions to prevent the spread of the pandemic, including in its membership (24) government agencies. Among the most important decisions taken: suspending Umrah, education, and all international and domestic flights, starting extensive field survey operations, expanding laboratory capacity, also partial then total curfew on various regions of the Kingdom, the decision to treat all citizens, residents, and irregulars for free without any consequences, and holding Hajj last year (1441 AH) with very limited numbers for those wishing to perform Hajj rituals from various nationalities present within the Kingdom (1). Health authorities warned against complacency in applying precautionary measures, emphasizing the importance of continuing to adhere to them until society reaches - God willing - safety (2).
